titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals (PETA) Research Files

controlnote.p: EAD generated by NCSU Libraries' Collection Guides application using data imported from ArchivesSpace.

maintenanceagency.agencyname: North Carolina State University Libraries, Special Collections Research Center

corpname.part: People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals

did.unittitle: People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals (PETA) Research Files
did.abstract: Clippings, tear sheets, reprints, offprints, reports, newsletters, copies of articles from magazines and newspapers, and other printed, typescript, or photocopied items compiled by People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals (PETA), from their earliest days through 2001. Among the subjects included are smuggling and poaching, genetic engineering, drug testing, pest control experimentation, alternatives to animal testing, xenografts, transplants, and military use of animals for wound experimentation.

People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals (PETA) was established in 1980 with offices in Norfolk, Virginia. The organization now extends throughout the world with affiliates in the United Kingdom, Germany, the Netherlands, India, Italy, Greece, and Australia. Since its establishment it has worked to effect major changes in the treatment of animals by bringing together members of the scientific, judicial, and legislative communities.
did.physloc: For current information on the location of these materials, please consult the Special Collections Research Center Reference Staff.

corpname.part: North Carolina State University Libraries, Special Collections Research Center

arrangement.p: The collection is organized into nine series: 1. Anti-Animal Organizations,2. Pro-Animal Organizations,3. Progressive Organizations,4. Experimentation,5. Genetic Engineering,6. Pest Control,7. Confidential Subject Files,8. Subject Files,9. Other Files.

bioghist.p: People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals (PETA) was established in 1980 with offices in Norfolk, Virginia, but now extends throughout the world with affiliates in the United Kingdom, Germany, the Netherlands, India, Italy, Greece, and Australia. Since its establishment it has worked through public education, cruelty investigations, research, animal rescue, legislation, special events, celebrity involvement, and protest campaigns to effect change in the treatment of animals.

prefercite.p: [Identification of item], People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals (PETA) Research Files, MC 353, Special Collections Research Center, North Carolina State University Libraries, Raleigh, NC

processinfo.p: Processed by Michael Watts, Keith Taylor, Judy Allen Dodson, May 2006

scopecontent.p: Clippings, tear sheets, reprints, offprints, reports, newsletters, copies of articles from magazines and newspapers, and other printed, typescript, or photocopied items compiled by People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals (PETA), from their earliest days through 2001. The list of subjects in the file index includes smuggling and poaching, genetic engineering, drug testing, pest control experimentation, alternatives to animal testing, xenografts, transplants and military destruction and mutilation of animals for wound experimentation.
The collection has an extensive assembly of information about both "pro animal rights" organizations and about organizations that are regarded as antipathetic to the cause of animals.

userestrict.p: The nature of the NCSU Libraries' Special Collections means that copyright or other information about restrictions may be difficult or even impossible to determine despite reasonable efforts. The NCSU Libraries claims only physical ownership of most Special Collections materials.

The materials from our collections are made available for use in research, teaching, and private study, pursuant to U.S. Copyright law. The user must assume full responsibility for any use of the materials, including but not limited to, infringement of copyright and publication rights of reproduced materials. Any materials used for academic research or otherwise should be fully credited with the source.

Unreliability (of Animal Models)—General/Miscellaneous. Question of objectivity in Biomedical Research; burn research with animals; horror stories of the treatment of live animals, especially rats and dogs. Clippings and photocopies from newspapers - 1 of 2

Genetic Engineering—Cloning. ONAL; Arizona Republic; Sunday Times; Washington Post; Telegraph; New Scientist; Guardian—Ethical issues for humans and the treatment of animals—more beef, richer milk; animal rights in the age of cloning (Newsday, New York, May 13, 1997); human cloning—the debate (Christian Science Monitor);Dolly, ethics; articles and photocopies - 1 of 8

Genetic Engineering—Drug Production. The DNA experiment; genetic alteration; breeding and cross breeding (monk Gregor Mendel breeds and cross breeds 22 strains of peas. Biotechnology; mice engineering to produce protein to protect against heart attack, cancer, and pigs produce anti-clot protein

Genetic Engineering—General—1986 and before or no date. “A Science Report,” by Ed Regis, Omni, n.d. Gina Maranto, “Genetic Engineering: Hype, Hubris, and Haste,” Discover, June 1986, pp. 50 ff. The debate, doubts,
Genetic Engineering—General—1987. Conflict between Rifkin and the “biotech farm.” Conflict and ethics. GAO: Biotechnology: Role of Institutional Biosafety Committees, December 1987: GAO/RCED-88-64BR.

Genetic Engineering—General—1988. Animal patents—mice engineered to be more susceptible to cancer: Veterinarians involved in animal welfare groups are outraged by the government’s decision to patent an animal: Dr. Michael Fox, Vice President/Bioethics and Farm Animals of the Humane Society of the US, says, “This decision reflects an attitude towards creation as mere ownable property. This is a tragic backwards step for this nation to take.” DMV, June 1988, pp. 1 and 14. Article in The Washington Post Magazine, January 17, 1988, “Jeremy Rifkin Is a Little Worried about your Future,” by David Van Biema.

Genetic Engineering—General—1989. Rifkin blocks ‘gene therapy’ trials on humans in New Scientist,4 February 1989. “Rifkin: the scourge of biotechnologists.” Transgenic mice, smaller mice for more experiments.
Genetic Engineering—General—1991. The human gnome project. Andrej Klimowski, “The Frankenstein Factor,” Weekend Guardian, Saturday-Sunday, Marcy 16-17, 1991; mice custom designed for research.
Genetic Engineering—General—1994 Leap from lab to medicine is difficult.
Genetic Engineering—General—1996. Man-beast: perilous Mix? London Daily Telegraph, February 18, 1996. “Splicing animal regulations,” The Nation, March 11, 1996, pp. 16 ff.

Genetic Engineering—Patents. Technology and Law (Washington Post, August 20, 1987). Patent office and “gene-customized animals.” Churches unite to halt human gene patents. Patents granted for three types of laboratory mice. Animal patents stirs controversy, ethics concerns among DVMs. New York Times, editorial, April 21, 1987 “Yes, Patent Life.” “Mouse patent is issued to Harvart, World’s First for Higher Life Form. NYT, Wed, Apr. 13, 1988. “Mouse patent produces traps: The ownership of a genetically altered life form raises ethical and social issues,” Globe & Mail, Sept. 3, 1994. CAPA (Coalition against the Patenting of Animals from The Humane Society of the United States; 1994?)- 1 of 4

Genetics (General)—1998 About animal research (slender folder) “Genetic trespassing and environmental ethics,’ Dr. Mira Fong, Center for Global Philosophy, Santa Fe, NM; article about Jeremy Rifkin, president of the Foundation on Economic Trends—to seek a patent to prevent creation of animal-human creature—animals that carry human genes, from the San Francisco Chronicle, April 3, 1988.
Hair. Alopecia and the assistance of rats in solving the problem of baldness induced by chemotherapy (Wall Street Journal, Friday, September 28, 1990). (Slender file).

Head Injury. Animals used. Booklet with list of system Projects using non-human mammals to study human impact and trauma. A Few of the federally-funded projects categorized as a waste of tax dollars and animal life (Medical Research Modernization Committee 1985?); head injuries in the chimpanzee. Bashing of cat’s skulls - 1 of 3

Hearing/Noise. Testing for jet-noise stress; dolphins and the results of explosions. Annotated bibliography: Anthony P. Majors and Albert C. Myrick, “Effects of Noise on Animals: Implications for Dolphins exposed to Seal Bombs in the Eastern Tropical Pacific Purse-Seine Fishery,” November 1989, 46 pp.

Heat Stroke/Temperature. Treatment of animals to see how they respond to heat. “Animal agony and heat stroke research” from Animal Welfare Act: Unreported Crimes?” United Action for Animals, Inc. Treatment of baboons in a study by Duane W. Proppe of the Department of Physiology, University of Texas Health Sciene Center at San Antonio.(Leg Blood Flow in Heat-Stressed dehydrated Baboons, 1986,)
Type of Experiment—Gunshot wounds. Dog used as subject.
